document.title: Pritzker College Prep's Adaptation of Stanford History Education Group's Historical Thinking Skills

DEB6B5D2BF0146ADA5C46BE7D27A8CB4.description: Approaching documents through an analytical lens, SWBAT decipher and evaluate the arguments made by two or more sources on a particular subject in order to answer a central question about that subject in an objective manner.

B45FA2B20F7C4F0C87ADEED1AF260B2E.description: Approaching multiple documents like a journalist or detective weighs evidence, SWBAT identify similarities and differences across sources in order to construct a most-likely narrative given the evidence.

74918E3333B74160A91FF0AF36FD9684.description: Approaching the text as one tree in the wider forest, SWBAT situate the document in its time and place and determine how those factors shaped the document’s creation.

62709B61CC36412BBBFC40F9562BF9C7.description: Approaching the text with an acute attention to detail and the ability to inference and make connections, SWBAT identify key information and draw relevant, defensible conclusions.

B70A1837B7F7428CB42AD56A8760CA2F.description: Approaching the source through a questioning lens, SWBAT identify key sourcing information (e.g. point of view, historical situation, audience, and purpose) and analyze how the most relevant aspects of the source impact the reader’s interpretation of its content.
